(1) Since p1=::>(p1||p2) is a Truth Formula and ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula, the conjunction of a Truth Formula and a Falsehood Formula is always a Falsehood Formula. So the answer for (1) is B.
(2) The disjunction of a Truth Formula and a Falsehood Formula is always a Truth Formula. So the answer for (2) is A.

The final answer is: [[B];[A]]

Using Basic Equivalence (10): \(A > B ::=:: \neg A | B\), we can rewrite \((p > q) > r\) as:

\[
\begin{align*}
&(\neg p | q) > r\\
&=\neg(\neg p | q)| r\\
&=(p & \neg q)| r
\end{align*}
\]

Let's analyze the two expressions:
\[
\begin{align*}
(p > q) > r &\equiv (!p | q) > r\\
&\equiv!(!p | q) | r\\
&\equiv (p &!q) | r\\
\end{align*}
\]

\[
\begin{align*}
p > (q > r) &\equiv p > (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p | (!q | r)\\
&\equiv!p |!q | r
\end{align*}
\]

It is clear that \((p &!q) | r\) is not equivalent to \(!p |!q | r\). So the answer is [[B]].

For the first expression:
\[
\begin{align*}
&!(p>(p|q))\land r\\
=&!(!p|(p|q))\land r\\
=&(!!p&\land!(p|q))\land r\\
=&(p&\land(!p&\land!q))\land r\\
=&(p&\land!p&\land!q)\land r\\
=&(0&\land!q)\land r\\
=&0\land r\\
=&0
\end{align*}
\]

For the second expression:
\[
\begin{align*}
&p\land(((p|q)\land!p)>q)\\
=&p\land(!((p|q)\land!p)|q)\\
=&p\land((!(p|q)|p)|q)\\
=&p\land(((!p&\land!q)|p)|q)\\
=&p\land(((!p|p)&(\!q|p))|q)\\
=&p\land((1&(\!q|p))|q)\\
=&p\land((\!q|p)|q)\\
=&p\land((!q|q)|p)\\
=&p\land(1|p)\\
=&p\land 1\\
=&p
\end{align*}
\]

So, the answers are [[!(p>(p|q))&r;0];[p&(((p|q)&!p)>q);p]].

To express this as a percentage, we multiply by 100: `0.75 * 100 = 75`.

So, the answer is [[75%]]
